comments.commentBody: I just figured out your initials, 'Owie.  So I guess I rememberd correctly about Barry's alter ego.
KS  can be my BF Forever. So can SK.

My heart felt thanks to the team of KS and Sara K, for a most interesting journey through a class of Journalism 101.
Now they've only to say WEN!

Howie
"Nobody goes there anymore" is what Yogi actually said.  I meant to type "Nobody lives there anymore..."

I know this will seem strange to many Catholics, but in many Protestant churches mobile phones and iPads are becoming welcomed and integrated into the services. References and other relevant material for readings and sermons are posted and discussion with other members during the service is encouraged. Prior to the electronic age, many of the Protestant churches had this information in the bulletin and to this day many Protestant church attendees will bring a notebook & pen to take notes with.

A study done at the University of Texas found that people remember (Metcalf 1997):

10 percent of what they read;
20 percent of what they hear;
30 percent of what they see;
50 percent of what they see and hear;
70 percent of what they say; and
90 percent of what they do and say

While texting wasn't as popular in 1997 when the study was done, I think it's safe to assume it'd be somewhere in the 50-70% range from that chart. This is certainly far better than the near-zero percent retention of last Sunday's Mass which most Catholics could remember, that is if they bothered to go to Mass at all.

This weekend I was at Mass @ St. Pat's with my parents. I was there in the pew with my phone on the whole time. I have several bible translations, numerous bible & Christian resources, and yes, a complete copy of The Roman Missal, 3rd Edition. I'm willing to bet 99% of the people in attendance don't even own a paper copy of The Missal, nor ever looked at one outside of a church. Sad.

Hollywood and Vine, WEREWOLVES are known to hang out!

My blog http://toddlefast.blogspot.com/ is about bilingual educational activities for me and my toddler. I actually started it because I was struggling with post-partum depression and needed to push myself to have meaningful interactions with my daughter and feel good about myself as a mother.

Some other things one might discuss:

* Barriers to entry, and monopoly pricing power. Do gov
safety regulations create healthcare monopolies. Prove
or disprove: for hospitals, for doctors.

* Are all healthcare expenditures `taxes'. What is a `tax';
is it any involuntary fee that interferes with other markets?

* It would seem necessary to get hospital administrators
to level fund their yearly budgets. How do you do this?
How about bringing in a few to talk about it.

* Would the slogan - if its regulated and necessary it must
be affordable - be politically sound?

"If you want to get rich you S.O.B. I'll tell you what to do, never sit down with a tear or a frown, and paddle your own CANOE!"

H

My feeling for some years now, as a naturalist who has sought in vain for an objective foundation for morality/ethics, is that the best we can ever hope for are explanations of our moral intuitions/judgments/rules etc. but can never reach anything like a moral justification of them.

I am sure I am right until I realize I am wrong and then I am sure I was wrong but am right now.

Very true, Mark! What's more, our cops and prosecutors are reluctant to carry out their missions. As evidenced in Senator Elizabeth Warren's first banking committee appearance, the banks are not only too big to fail, but apparently too big to prosecute.

I agree with previous comment. To that I would add that if RD would return to the format that made it great I would subscribe again. Today it is broken up into innumerable small tidbits. Where there used to be 10-15 real articles, there are now 3 or 4 and the rest is too disjointed to care about.  Do they think we all have the attention span of a gnat?

Reader's Digest has always been a lightweight, vaguely right wing piece of fluff that appeals to the intellectually challenged. Why would it continue to exist when there are countless even less challenging "reality" shows on television.

Rest in Peace Reader's Digest.... Your day is past.

To bail out too big to fail banks, middle class thrift had to be thrown under the bus.

The substitution of monetary policy for fiscal policy is an ethical as well as a practical disaster.
An entire generation lost its sense of humor reading their stupid joke pages.

More insider trading. Meh. Will the Financial Fraud Enforcement Force take the credit to hide the fact that these incompetents haven't indicted anyone for fraud, drug money laundering, LIBOR manipulation, RMBS and CDO fraud? Will Lanny Breuer wave this as a banner on his way out the door and to his reward for faithful service to the Lords of Wall Street?

Maybe if RD stopped paying out huge chunks of cash in pork spending (huge bonuses to execs, payment of questionable exec expenses, unnecessary office space and other frivolous outlays they just might get out of the mess the college boys have put them in.
Plus, the pleadings should have a title, "This could happen to you."
The Court should make a special exception and allow Readers Digest to file condensed pleadings on smaller than 81/2 by 11 paper.
Seeing is believing and talk is cheap.

I almost recommended this.  But for your last point you buy into the lie that Keystone is about US oil imports.  It's not.  It's about US oil exports.  This pipeline is a way to turn the US into a courier who skims a little off the top for services provided.  And who shoulders all the risks of transporting a dangerous substance...  Well, you and I shoulder the risk, and the profits go to the Cayman Islands.

Netliner:  The problem with wind is all the eco-freaks stopping them because they allegedly kill birds.  Guess they haven't seen the great lines of wind farms of Denmark, which made a conscious decision to be free of mid-East oil over a decade ago and they are today.  Hydro is even worse.  The salmon freaks want all the dams that produce hydro removed, especially on the Snake river.  Biomass is being defeated wherever it is proposed by NIMBY'S AND BANANA'S (Build Absolutely Nothing Anywhere Near Anything).  Our community just defeated one.  Not going to happen.  That just leaves solar and we certainly don't need another Solyndra, et. al.  So, three of your four solutions are regularly fought by your eco-brothers-in-arms and the fourth hasn't yet come to fruition.  Joe is right, carbon is the energy for now because Nuclear is fought even more vigorously than any other form of energy production.  When all you folks go off the grid, maybe the energy demand will drop and you'll live in a world without electricity.  Been there, done that, I like the genie in the wire.

A carbon tax on oil will only make tar sands more viable, if by some strange loophole, a Congressional specialty by the way, tar sands are not counted as oil. In fact tar sands release more CO2 than conventional and should be more highly taxed.

Joe, I usually agree with you on most issues, but you're wide of the mark here.

A carbon tax or similar tax scheme would make tar sand oil more viable, but would also make solar, wind, hydro, and biomass power more viable, too. Long run, this is desirable as we've probably reached peak oil production and need to tap other, cleaner sources of energy.

As well, the price of oil is influenced by favorable tax policies for the oil industry. Eliminate that, and oil is somewhat less favored.

With respect to U.S. demand for oil, this can be shaved by increasing fuel efficiency standards for transportation. While oil is used far less frequently to heat plants and buildings, oil demand in these sectors can readily be cut by retrofitting buildings and equipment.

One area in which we agree is that Keystone is a tough call. If the U.S. is going to import oil, better that we import it from Canada-- especially if the Canadian product is price competitive and provided that the pipeline is routed to minimize environmental concerns. But long run, oil is a diminishing resource whose environmental costs are prohibitive.

Bottom line: Far better to wean ourselves off oil sooner rather than later.
A third is a lack of a budget!

There are only two possible answers to "why?".  Either the regulatory agencies don't have litigation branches that have "the right stuff" (i.e., trial wimps), or, they had orders from Obama NOT to prosecute.  Either possibility, if proven, would make for great NYT headlines.

The mere fact that their announcement has been greeted with an echo of crickets chirping speaks volumes. I'm not a big fan of Staples but these two are so far out of the loop it is almost sad. And I shop there from time to time.
still no guts! a waste of tax dollars! prosecution sends the only reliable answer.

If the bank pleads, it helps with civil cases, but it won't really change behavior.

Only locking up C-Suite cheats will do that. LIBOR manipulation, money laundering and the rest of the crimes weren't accidents. They were done by humans who should be in jail instead of laughing all the way to the bank.

In 1962 Claude Lévy-Strauss published the results of years of study among aboriginal groups in Brazil and other countries and called Europeans’ belief in their history a superstition. He described unconscious mental structures of intelligence evident in all groups of people he had studied. He concluded that modern thinking cannot have achieved any qualitative progress over primitive thinking. A difference exists only to the extent that the thinking of primitives is untamed and that of modern, urban cultures is domesticated. Lévy-Strauss’s proof strikes even more sharply at moderns’ belief in ethnocentricity. His research showed that despite their so-called backwardness primitives rather than moderns possessed a marked advantage: they remained in a very close relationship with the totality of their world while modern man had become an alienated component of his. He also concluded that many modern ethnographers and philosophers harbor a deep misconception about primitive peoples: that the advantage of the primitive would be more than counterbalanced by an advantage possessed by modern man, namely that he is master of independent reason while the primitive is subject to the dominance of affects. He showed that although many of his contemporaries claimed they had explained the inferiority of primitives concerning rationality his studies refuted this ethnocentric concept. His work showed that while primitives think in a different way than we do they are no less rational.
